articles.headline: The Pogie Awards for the Year’s Best Tech Ideas
articles.snippet: The great, clever features of the year that somehow made it past the obstacles of cost, engineering and lawyers.
articles.abstract: The great, clever features of the year that somehow made it past the obstacles of cost, engineering and lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wow, what an opportunity! Imagine having a newspaper column published precisely on the last day of the year. What a chance to step back, look ahead, sum it all up!

articles.headline: Suicide Bomber Killed C.I.A. Operatives
articles.snippet: A suicide bomber killed at least eight American civilians, most of them C.I.A. officers, at a remote base in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A suicide bomber killed at least eight American civilians, most of them C.I.A. officers, at a remote base in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber wearing an explosive vest killed at least eight American civilians, most of them C.I.A. officers, at a remote base in southeastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, according to NATO officials and former American intelligence officials.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: YouTube’s Quest to Suggest More
articles.snippet: Engineers are fine-tuning the site to get visitors to stay longer and treat it more like regular old television.
articles.abstract: Engineers are fine-tuning the site to get visitors to stay longer and treat it more like regular old television.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BRUNO, Calif.  YouTube, the video site owned by Google, is about 10 times more popular than its nearest competitor. But Hunter Walk still thinks of it as an underdog.

articles.headline: A Mideast Bond, Stitched of Pain and Healing
articles.snippet: The friendship between two children in a hospital — a Palestinian and an Israeli — has drawn their parents into a kinship that defies national struggle.
articles.abstract: The friendship between two children in a hospital — a Palestinian and an Israeli — has drawn their parents into a kinship that defies national struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  He can be impulsive. She has a touch of bossiness. Next-door neighbors for nearly a year, they talk, watch television and explore the world together, wandering into each other’s homes without a second thought. She likes his mother’s eggplant dish. He likes her father’s rice and lamb.

articles.headline: At McDonald’s, a Retirement Stirs Questions
articles.snippet: Ralph Alvarez’s departure is the second time in a little more than three years that the company’s No. 2 executive has left suddenly.
articles.abstract: Ralph Alvarez’s departure is the second time in a little more than three years that the company’s No. 2 executive has left suddenly.
articles.lead_paragraph: After McDonald’s lost two chief executives to fatal illness in rapid succession in 2004, the company was praised for managing a smooth transition. But the unexpected departure this month of its No. 2 executive, Ralph Alvarez, raises concerns that the fast food giant may have lost its touch in planning for changes at the top.

articles.headline: Heart-Stopping Fall, Breathtaking Rally
articles.snippet: In one of the most volatile years in stock market history, a rally replenished half the losses from the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: In one of the most volatile years in stock market history, a rally replenished half the losses from the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was the year that Wall Street turned a crash into a bang.

articles.headline: Spy Agencies Failed to Collate Clues on Terror
articles.snippet: The National Security Agency intercepted discussions of a plot by leaders of Al Qaeda in Yemen, but spy agencies did not combine the intercepts with other information.
articles.abstract: The National Security Agency intercepted discussions of a plot by leaders of Al Qaeda in Yemen, but spy agencies did not combine the intercepts with other information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency four months ago intercepted conversations among leaders of Al Qaeda in Yemen discussing a plot to use a Nigerian man for a coming terrorist attack, but American spy agencies later failed to combine the intercepts with other information that might have disrupted last week’s attempted airline bombing.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Shadow of 9/11 Is Cast Again
articles.snippet: Terrorism experts followed the Detroit story with dismay.
articles.abstract: Terrorism experts followed the Detroit story with dismay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The finger-pointing began in earnest on Wednesday over who in the alphabet soup of American security agencies knew what and when about the Nigerian man charged with trying to blow up an airliner.

articles.headline: The Worst May Not Be Over for Europe
articles.snippet: The latest concern is that Greece or another weak economy might default on its sovereign debt, potentially fracturing the euro zone.
articles.abstract: The latest concern is that Greece or another weak economy might default on its sovereign debt, potentially fracturing the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Never before has Europe’s monetary union seemed so fragile.

articles.headline: Safety of Beef Processing Method Is Questioned
articles.snippet: E. coli and salmonella have been found dozens of times in meat processed with a novel ammonia treatment.
articles.abstract: E. coli and salmonella have been found dozens of times in meat processed with a novel ammonia treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, federal officials were struggling to remove potentially deadly E. coli from hamburgers when an entrepreneurial company from South Dakota came up with a novel idea: injecting beef with ammonia.

articles.headline: A Volatile Final Minute in a Good Year for Stocks
articles.snippet: Shares fell substantially on 2009’s last day, but that did not dampen enthusiasm over what was a comeback year.
articles.abstract: Shares fell substantially on 2009’s last day, but that did not dampen enthusiasm over what was a comeback year.
articles.lead_paragraph: After one of the most volatile decades in Wall Street history, Thursday brought a glimmer of hope, as optimism over the strength of economic recovery helped keep markets near their highest levels in 14 months.
